subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Call of Cthulhu: Typo Report, paragraphs 4 and 6
msgSnippet: ... That is merged, not unmerged:  syllabic consonants are phonemically /@/. Among North Americans, it s mostly Southerners who are still unmerged. ...
messageBody:
Nathan Sharfi scripsit:

> As for "chicken", I'd call it unmerged here; I'd pronounce it as [n=].

That is merged, not unmerged: syllabic consonants are phonemically /@/.
Among North Americans, it's mostly Southerners who are still unmerged.

> It's always been [eI] for me but I checked around and OS X's OED for US
> (IPA) uses [E] and Wiktionary uses [{]. [{], then?

Certainly [{] is the right vowel for folks with no Mary-marry-merry
merger. Since you have [eI], you probably merge all three, but the ODO
(rather than OED, I think?) writes [Er] and means [eIr]. Southerners have
a Mary-merry merger, but marry (and therefore caricature) is distinct.

Computer folks from merged regions pronounce "char" (short for
"character") as /keIr/, but for unmerged me it would have to be /kær/,
which violates English phonotactics. Consequently, I use the spelling
pronunciation /tSAr/.

--
John Cowan <cowan@...> http://www.ccil.org/~cowan
The internet is a web of tiny tyrannies giving an illusion of anarchy.
--David Rush
